marketNews.title: Compilation of Share Buybacks by Issuers
marketNews.content: A number of issuers have announced share buyback plans amid market volatility. This step is also supported by the OJK relaxation which allows issuers to conduct share buybacks without AGM approval for 6 months starting from March 19, 2025. Below is a compilation of share buyback plans announced by issuers, both through AGM approval and without AGM approval:

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content: We assess that the buybacks by issuers, as well as several buybacks by controllers and directors, have the potential to foster optimism among domestic market players. However, for a more significant IHSG recovery, increased foreign investor confidence is needed so that the foreign outflow trend can reverse. Since the beginning of 2025, the IHSG has recorded a net foreign outflow of IDR 49.5 trillion as of Thursday (April 17).

marketNews.title: PTPP 1Q25: New Contract Value +32% YoY
marketNews.content: 1. PTPP: PT PP recorded new contract value of approximately IDR 6.3 trillion during 1Q25 (+32% YoY), equivalent to 21% of the 2025 target. The realization came from State-Owned Enterprise projects by 52.1%, private by 28.6%, and government by 19.3%. Based on the type of work, the port sector contributed 37.2%, followed by buildings (32.9%), roads and bridges (22.6%), dams (4.3%), irrigation (2.8%), and oil and gas (0.3%). 2. SMRA: Summarecon Agung recorded marketing sales of IDR 877 billion in 1Q25 (+8% YoY, -49% QoQ), equivalent to 17.5% of the 2025 target of IDR 5 trillion. The housing segment contributed 75% of marketing sales in 1Q25, followed by shop-houses (22%), apartments (2%), and land plots and offices each below 1%. 3. DMAS: Puradelta Lestari recorded marketing sales of IDR 466 billion in 1Q25 (-17% YoY, +9% QoQ), equivalent to ~26% of the 2025 target of IDR 1.81 trillion. DMAS Director & Corporate Secretary, Tondy Suwanto, stated that the company recorded industrial land sales of 14.2 hectares in 1Q25, with 86% originating from the data center sector. Tondy also mentioned that there is still industrial land demand of ~80 hectares, so they are optimistic about achieving the 2025 marketing sales target. 4. CLEO: Sariguna Primatirta plans to distribute bonus shares worth IDR 240 billion from share premium in a 1:1 ratio. The cum date on the regular and negotiation market is June 5, 2025, with distribution on June 26, 2025. This plan will be discussed in the EGM on May 26, 2025. 5. TPIA: Chandra Asri Pacific through its subsidiary, Chandra Daya Investasi, signed an agreement to purchase 50.99% of shares in PT Chandra Shipping International and PT Marina Indah Maritim, with the transaction values yet to be announced. Following these transactions, PT Chandra Daya Investasi holds 99.9% of shares in PT Chandra Shipping International and PT Marina Indah Maritim. 6. EXCL: One of the controllers of XLSmart Telecom Sejahtera, Axiata Investments (Indonesia) Sdn. Bhd., sold 2.4 billion EXCL shares at a price of IDR 3,189 per share or totaling IDR 7.6 trillion to entities owned by the Sinar Mas group. This transaction is part of the merger between EXCL and Smartfren Telecom (FREN). After this transaction, Axiata Investments (Indonesia) Sdn. Bhd.'s ownership in EXCL decreased from 66.25% to 34.8%, and contributed IDR 7.6 trillion to the foreign outflow data on Wednesday (April 16). The IDX also officially removed the listing of FREN shares (delisting) on Thursday (April 17), following the completion of the merger between FREN and EXCL. 7. BJBR: Bank Pembangunan Daerah Jawa Barat dan Banten shareholders on Wednesday (April 16) appointed Mardigu Wowiek Prasantyo as president commissioner, Helmy Yahya as independent commissioner, and Yusuf Saadudin as president director. BJBR shareholders also approved the plan to distribute 2024 fiscal year dividends amounting to ~IDR 897 billion or ~IDR 85.3 per share, equivalent to a 65.5% dividend payout ratio and indicating a dividend yield of 9.7% as of Thursday (April 17). The cum date and dividend payment date have not been announced. 8. ESSA: ESSA Industries Indonesia will distribute 2024 fiscal year dividends amounting to ~IDR 172.3 billion or IDR 10 per share, equivalent to a 25% dividend payout ratio. The cum date and payment date have not been announced. Referring to the ESSA share price at the close of trading on Thursday (April 17) at IDR 615 per share, the indicated dividend yield is 1.6%.

marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics You Need to Know...
marketNews.content: 1. Gold prices in the spot market briefly touched an all-time high of 3,357 US dollars per troy ounce during intraday trading on Wednesday (April 16), before closing at 3,342 US dollars per troy ounce (+3.5%). Since the beginning of 2025, gold prices have surged about 700 US dollars per troy ounce (+27.6% YTD), supported by global uncertainty and the weakening US dollar due to trade war escalation. On Thursday (April 17), gold prices weakened -0.53% to 3,325 US dollars per troy ounce. 2. Newcastle forward coal prices for April 2025 fell -1.3% to 94.25 US dollars per ton on Wednesday (April 16), marking the lowest level since May 2021. Coal prices themselves have plummeted in recent months in line with declining demand from China, which is experiencing oversupply, while China's monthly coal production reached an all-time high in March 2025. 3. Chinese President, Xi Jinping, on Thursday (April 17) promoted the idea of an "Asian family" and called for regional unity to counter US pressure on other countries to limit trade relations with China. This idea was conveyed by Xi during his visit to Cambodia, which concluded his Southeast Asia tour this week after visiting Vietnam and Malaysia. 4. The US Census Bureau recorded that US retail sales surged +1.4% MoM in March 2025 (vs. Feb 2025: +0.2% MoM), exceeding consensus expectations of +1.3% MoM and marking the largest growth since January 2023. This realization was driven by increased motor vehicle and parts sales (+5.3% MoM), in line with accelerated purchasing to avoid import tariffs. Excluding automotive, US retail sales grew +0.5% MoM in March 2025. Meanwhile, core retail sales - whose movement is similar to the consumer spending component of US GDP data - grew +0.4% MoM (vs. Feb 2025: +1% MoM), lower than consensus expectations of +0.6% MoM. 5. The Fed Chair, Jerome Powell, said on Wednesday (April 16) that the Fed will wait for more data on the direction of the economy before changing interest rates. Powell also warned that the tariff policy from US President, Donald Trump, risks pushing inflation and unemployment further away from the Fed's targets. Powell also mentioned that US economic growth appears to be slowing with consumer spending growing moderately. Furthermore, Powell stated that the surge in imports to avoid tariff implementation dates is likely to put pressure on US GDP estimates. 6. The US Department of State said on Wednesday (April 16) that US Secretary of State, Marco Rubio, had met with Indonesian Foreign Minister, Sugiono, to discuss tariff negotiations as well as deepening defense and security cooperation. The US Department of State also said that Rubio welcomed Indonesia's efforts. Previously, in a tariff negotiation proposal with the US government, the Indonesian government proposed importing around 18-19 billion US dollars of US goods and offered Indonesian State-Owned Enterprises to invest in the US oil, gas, and information technology sectors. 7. The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources on Wednesday (April 16) awarded 5 oil and gas blocks to auction winners as an effort to replenish oil and gas reserves. Reuters reported that the government plans to offer nearly 60 oil and gas blocks in the coming years to reverse the decline in production that has occurred over the last decade. 8. The European Union regulator changed the submission period for deforestation law import compliance documents to once a year, lighter than the previous rule which required importers to submit documents with every shipment. This regulatory relief emerged after pressure from the industry, as well as following the postponement of the implementation of the anti-deforestation law for 1 year to December 30, 2025. In June 2025, EU regulators will release categories for importing countries into 'high risk', 'standard', or 'low risk' groups, where imports from low-risk countries will receive relief on compliance requirements for the regulation.

marketNews.content: "Getting trapped in FOMO at a false Fibonacci-breakout level is often a broker's trick to ensnare retail traders who put too much faith in a single indicator." - FeryCitraF
